data.text: Bikepacking Hammock Setup Ultralight Rainfly

So I did a little one night trip this weekend, just for fun and to enjoy/test out my gear. Filled my backpack with my camping gear and went. Probably the biggest fail of the gear was my "rainfly" (polysil window insulation). What are some suggestions for an ultralight rainfly? One of my thoughts was trying again and maybe getting some shock cord to attach it to either the trees or further up my hammock straps. Has anyone tried the hummingbird gear hammock straps? Any other UL hammock straps that are worth it? Thanks!

The classic hammock/tarp layout, uses a ridge line, you can use para cord, or you do get lighter cord out there such as amsteel. This can be tied to the trees, or any point along the hammock attachment line to the trees. The minimum connection point is about 15 cm on the webbing each end before your hammock connectors. The tarp then hangs over this ridge line. The tarp is attache to the ridge-line and tensioned using a running knot such as a prusik loop. The ridge line takes the weight of the fly, without creating too much tension in it . This will keep the material away from your face, the higher up the connection line you go, the more headroom you have in the hammock.....but the more material you need for the tarp to still keep the hammock sheltered from rain. A silnylon tarp can be quite cheap, cuban fibre is incredible light.....but very rustley and more expensive. Woven material is generally stronger than plastic sheeting, and one would generally look to guy the corners out. Hope that helps, but I am sure seasoned hammockers can give better insight.
data.author: Graeme Thomson

data.text:
So you may have opened a whole can of worms here. There are a variety of different hanging options for ultralighters. Whoopie slings, dyneema straps, dyneema ropes, Dutchware products, holy moly it goes on and on. I just went down this rabbit hole myself over the weekend and I've probably decided on a simple set of plan dyneema straps from Ripstop By The Roll with a universal loop from Jeff Myers. Light, cheap, but not at simple as my older strap setup. The 10oz saving will make it worth it, though. Here's a place to start from: WARNING, rabbit hole... https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l4wTe5AZS2Y
ULTRALIGHT HAMMOCK SUSPENSIONS
youtube.com
data.author: Joshua Ulery

data.text: looks like the dyneema from rip stop by the roll is no longer available?
data.author: Kathryn Hoffberg

data.text:

data.author: Joshua Ulery

data.text: oh, looks like they updated it then and the previous version was discontinued
data.author: Kathryn Hoffberg

data.text: Almost every town has a pavilion. You can also try a one person bivvy. Hammocks are too much of a hassle.
data.author: Aaron Lad

data.text: great input. Doesn't answer my questions. As you see in this picture there is no pavilion. As you can't see in the picture, I have a bivy inside the hammock. Keeping to the UL mindset I left my tent at home and popped everything in a backpack and set out on this trip. I didn't find the hammock to be a hassle, just my setup something that could be improved upon.
data.author: Kathryn Hoffberg

data.text: oh. I didn't know it was a question. I was giving some input for you or the next person, so that a better time can be had. The one place I found hammock necessary is in central America where there are crabs crawling around. Nothing persona, and no offense or anything. Live & learn.
data.author: Aaron Lad

data.text: I cannot see a bivvy in the picture. Bivvys usually have one small tent pole.
data.author: Aaron Lad

data.text: only hooped bivibags have hoops, more often they are simply a zipped bag
data.author: Steve Barrett

data.text: a zipped bag? .hehe where I come from that's called a sleeping bag 😄
data.author: Aaron Lad

data.text: 😤 a zipped gore-Tex bag over the top
data.author: Steve Barrett

data.text: how is it held up?
data.author: Aaron Lad

data.text: it’s not. I sleep on my side so have no issues, with some you can tie some paracord to the flap to hold it up with some mozzie net to keep the bugs away, but it never bothered me in all the years for 100’s of nights that I’ve used one including in the army. You need to keep the zip open a little so you can breath 😉 and to prevent condensation. If I know it’s going to be really wet I’ll put a small tent fly above otherwise I wouldn’t bother. Perfect way for a light set up ( for me at least) You can get even simpler ones with a draw string closure so it’s meant more for condensation protection for the sleeping bag rather than full rain protection.
data.author: Steve Barrett

data.text: a basic, lightweight version- would need to be used with a fly.
data.author: Steve Barrett

data.text: so your bivvy isn't held up with anything; it's just a bag that goes over your sleeping bag? My mummy sleeping bag that I use has a drawstring that completely closes the bag..it's called a sleeping bag, not a bivvy. Where I come from bivvys are held up with a tent pole, and the bivvy acts as a small, one person tent the size of an average sleeping bag, so that a person can sleep in their sleeping bag with a low, upholstered ceiling, and without bugs or rain getting in.
data.author: Aaron Lad

data.text: the hooped Bivi is a newer variant, a bivi bag is ultimately a waterproof cover/bag to protect your sleeping bag. The hooped bivibags are adding weight to the point you can get full one man tents for the same weight. The non hooped are a lot more stealth as the have a very low profile - handy when you need creative sleeping spots when traveling like a botanical garden in the middle of a massive city 😎 Bivibags aren’t for everyone but I love them, but I wouldn’t touch a hooped bivi 🤷‍♂️
data.author: Steve Barrett

data.text: that makes sense. But I have only ever seen bivvys with a tent pole. The confusion may be caused from marketers marketing their products under a name used by a different application. So much confusion in the marketplace these days because marketers are deceptive.
data.author: Aaron Lad

data.text: the one I have is like this, but there's a short ~1' zipper to help get in. It is waterproof and emergency type reflective inside
data.author: Kathryn Hoffberg

data.text: Just get a tarp and tie a line above the hammock separately. I have a hammock that is designed with a rainfly and tent poles that keep it looped around.
data.author: Gerald Raton

data.text: I’m curious why you wouldn’t just use a poncho? As someone earlier in the thread suggested, a ridge line made out of para cord with four pieces on each corner.
data.author: Brett McGowan
